extent.charseq: Lt. (then Gunner) Pharris was stunned and severely injured

ldc_scope.charseq: In charge of the ordnance repair party on the third deck when the first Japanese torpedo struck almost directly under his station, Lt. (then Gunner) Pharris was stunned and severely injured by the concussion which hurled him to the overhead and back to the deck

Twice rendered unconscious by the nauseous fumes and handicapped by his painful injuries, he persisted in his desperate efforts to speed up the supply of ammunition and at the same time repeatedly risked his life to enter flooding compartments and drag to safety unconscious shipmates who were gradually being submerged in oil

December 8, 1941, within less than an hour after a stirring, six-minute address by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Congress voted, with only one member dissenting, that a state of war

ldc_scope.charseq: On December 8, 1941, within less than an hour after a stirring, six-minute address by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Congress voted, with only one member dissenting, that a state of war existed between the United States and Japan, and empowered the President to wage war with all the resources of the country

extent.charseq: less than an hour after a stirring, six-minute address by President Franklin D. Roosevelt

extent.charseq: Four days after Pearl Harbor, December 11, 1941, Germany and Italy declared war on the United States

ldc_scope.charseq: Four days after Pearl Harbor, December 11, 1941, Germany and Italy declared war on the United States

Congress, this time without a dissenting vote, immediately recognized the existence of a state of war with Germany and Italy, and also rescinded an article of the Selective Service Act prohibiting the use of American armed forces beyond the Western Hemisphere
